Pour one-half of the batter into prepared pan.
Add the melted chocolate to the other half of the batter, and continue mixing until well blended (about 1/4 minute).
Pour the chocolate batter over the white batter. Then cut through batter with knife to streak colors through cake.
Bake in a moderate oven (350°) for 50 to 55 minutes. (A cake of this type may "crack open" on top during baking.)
Remove from oven, let stand in pan for a moment; then turn onto wire cooling rack. As soon as cake is cool, frost with desired icing.
notes:
For High Altitude Baking:
Up to 3500 feet: no adjustments are necessary.
3500-4500 ft.: Reduce Baking Powder by 1/4 tsp. No change to sugar.
4500-6000 ft.: Reduce Baking Powder by 2 tbsp. Reduce total sugar by 1/4 cup. Add 2 tbsp to each cup of liquid.
Over 6000 ft.: Reduce Baking Powder by 2 tbsp. Reduce total sugar by 1/2 cup. Add 2 tbsp to each cup of liquid.
If using phosphate-type baking powder, use 3/4 tsp for tartrate-type, use 4 1/4 tsp.
When mixed by hand, you can let the batter stand while you rest, but be sure the total mixing time is as specified.
There has been no change in the quality or baking characteristics of SOFTASILK. You may continue to use it with your favorite recipes just as you always have.

fields.name: Minute Rice, Rarebit,
fields.title: Minute Rice Rarebit
fields.description: A quick and easy cheesy rice dish made with Minute Rice, tomato soup, and cheddar cheese.
ingredients: 1 1/2 cups grated Cheddar Cheese (or 8 ounces process cheese, cubed)
instructions: Prepare Minute Rice according to package directions.
Heat tomato soup over low heat (do not boil).
Add cheese to the soup and stir until melted.
Season with Worcestershire sauce and cayenne.
Spoon the sauce over the rice.

fields.name: Chocolate Chipits Bread Pudding
fields.title: Chocolate Chipits Bread Pudding
fields.description: A classic bread pudding recipe featuring chocolate chips.
instructions: Place the bread cubes and All-Bran in a buttered baking dish.
Sprinkle half of the Chipits chocolate chips over the bread cubes.
In a separate bowl, beat the eggs, sugar, salt, milk, and vanilla extract.
Pour the egg mixture over the bread and Chipits.
Sprinkle the remaining Chipits chocolate chips over the top.
Place the baking dish in a pan of hot water.
Bake in a preheated moderate oven (325°F) for one hour.
fields.comment: This recipe highlights the use of Chipits, a popular brand of chocolate chips, emphasizing their importance in achieving the desired flavor profile.

fields.name: Vienese Pastries and Chipits Pudding
fields.title: Viennese Pastries and Chipits Jiffies
fields.description: Two no-bake dessert recipes featuring graham crackers, frosting, and chocolate chips.

Viennese Pastries: To make one "pastry," spread one graham cracker with frosting, top with a second cracker, and continue to alternate frosting and crackers until seven crackers have been frosted.
Cover the sides of the "pastry" with frosting as well.
Cut pastries diagonally in half to form triangles or slice thin.

Chipits Jiffies: Combine graham crackers, condensed milk, and Chipits.
Mix well together and pour into a greased 8-inch square pan.
Bake in a moderate oven (350°F) for 30 minutes.
Cut into squares while still warm and remove from pan.

fields.comment: These recipes seem to originate from a vintage advertisement or cookbook promoting Chipits chocolate chips.  No-bake desserts like these were popular in the mid-20th century for their ease of preparation.

fields.name: Delicious Peach Recipes
fields.title: Delicious Peach Recipes
fields.description: A collection of peach-based desserts featuring Peach Pie, Peach Shortcake, and Peach Gelatine.

ingredients.name: Clover Leaf whipped cream or unwhipped cream

instructions.step: Peach Pie - Pastry: Sift dry ingredients, cut in shortening and add water. Toss on floured cloth and roll to size of pie pan. Line pan and place same size floured pan on top and bake in 425° oven for 15 or 20 minutes. (Individual pie shells may be used.)
Peach Pie - Filling: Slice fresh peaches, sweeten to taste, and fill baked pie shell. Top with Clover Leaf whipped cream.

Peach Shortcake: Sift dry ingredients, cut in shortening, add egg and Clover Leaf milk. Drop by spoonfuls on a cookie sheet and pat to ½ inch thick. Bake in a hot oven (425°). Slice and butter while hot. Add sweetened peaches and top with Clover Leaf whipped cream or serve with unwhipped cream.

Peach Gelatine: Soak gelatine in cold water. Add hot water and stir until dissolved; add sugar. When it has reached room temperature, place in the refrigerator and chill. Add peaches when it starts to congeal and put into molds. Serve with Clover Leaf plain or whipped cream.

fields.comment: These recipes showcase the versatility of peaches in various dessert formats, from the classic pie to a lighter shortcake and a molded gelatine. The use of "Clover Leaf" branded products suggests a historical context, likely from a time when such brands were prominently featured in recipe promotions.

fields.name: Cloverleaf Ad Peaches And Cream
fields.title: Peaches and Cream
fields.description: A simple dessert of ripe peaches topped with rich Clover Leaf cream.
instructions: Slice the peaches.
Top with Clover Leaf Cream.
fields.comment: This advertisement highlights the popularity of simple, fresh desserts in the past, emphasizing the quality and purity of Clover Leaf dairy products.

fields.name: Chocolate, Cream, Nuts and Marshmallow Gooey Ness
fields.title: Fantasy Fudge
fields.description: A rich and decadent fudge made with chocolate, nuts, and marshmallows.
ingredients: 1 package (12 ounces or less) chocolate chips
instructions: Mix sugar and butter together.
Bring to a boil.
Boil for 12 minutes. Do not stir.
Remove from heat. Add chocolate chips, Hershey bar, Baker's Dot chocolate squares, nuts (if using), and vanilla.
Stir until melted and smooth.
Pour into a greased 9x13 inch pan.
Top with marshmallow topping.
fields.comment: This recipe is similar to a classic fudge recipe but with added marshmallow topping, hence the "Fantasy Fudge" name. Baker's Dot chocolate squares were a popular baking chocolate in the mid-20th century and may be hard to find now so using another semi sweet baking chocolate could be substituted.  Evaporated milk contributes to the creamy texture and sweetness of the fudge.

fields.name: Honey Grahams Recipes
fields.title: Honey Grahams Cream Pie
fields.description: A creamy pie with a graham cracker crust, topped with meringue.
ingredients: 20 Graham Crackers, rolled fine (1-2/3 cups crumbs)
instructions: Thoroughly blend together Graham Cracker crumbs, softened butter or margarine and sugar.
Press firmly into an even layer against bottom and sides of 9" pie plate.
Bake in moderately hot oven (375° F.) 8 minutes. Cool.
Scald milk in top of double boiler.
Mix together the sugar, cornstarch and salt.
Add to scalded milk slowly, stirring constantly and cook over hot water until mixture thickens.
Cover: cook 10 minutes longer.
Beat egg yolks: blend a little cooked mixture into egg yolks and then add gradually to mixture in double boiler.
Cook 2 minutes, stirring constantly. Cool; add vanilla.
Pour into Graham Cracker Crust and top with meringue.
Add salt to egg whites; beat stiff, but not dry.
Continue beating and gradually add sugar, beating until all sugar is added and egg whites stand up in peaks.
Spread on filling.
Bake in very hot oven (425° F.) 5 minutes.

fields.name: Frozen Salads
fields.title: Appetizing Frozen Salads
fields.description: A collection of frozen salad recipes including Frozen Cheese Salad, Frozen Fruit Salad, and Frozen Roquefort Salad.

Frozen Fruit Salad: 1/2 cup chopped black walnuts, pecans, or almonds

Frozen Roquefort Salad: 1 small can (or 2/3 cup) chilled evaporated milk

Frozen Cheese Salad: Mash cream cheese and blend in mayonnaise.
Fold in dates, pineapple, and cheese mixture lightly.
Press partition in place to freeze mixture in cubes.
Serve on crisp lettuce or watercress with or without salad dressing.

Frozen Fruit Salad: Drain fruit well. Cut apricots and peaches into 1/2-inch pieces and cherries in halves.
Cut marshmallows into eighths (tip: use scissors dipped in hot water).
Fold in lemon juice, mayonnaise, marshmallows, nuts, and fruit.
Pour at once into cold freezing trays.
Slice and serve on crisp lettuce leaves with or without salad dressing.

Frozen Roquefort Salad: Mash cream cheese and blend with mayonnaise.
Fold in lemon juice, then cheese mixture and watercress.
Pour at once into cold freezing tray.
Press partition in place to freeze mixture in cubes.
Serve on crisp lettuce leaves or watercress.

fields.comment: Frozen salads gained popularity in the mid-20th century as a refreshing and convenient dessert or side dish.  They offered a make-ahead option for entertaining and showcased the evolving refrigeration technologies of the time.

fields.name: Apples À La Mode
fields.title: Apples a la Mode
fields.description: A classic dessert of baked apples in lemon syrup, served with vanilla ice cream and nuts.
instructions: Combine sugar, water, and juice and grated rinds of 2 lemons.
Bring to a boil.
Wash the apples thoroughly, cut them in half, and remove cores.
Cook apples slowly in the syrup for 15 to 20 minutes, until they become transparent.
Do not overcook so they lose their shape.
Dip syrup over apples during cooking.
Chill apples in the syrup.
Arrange on a large serving plate and pile vanilla ice cream in the center; top with nut meats.
Serve with remaining syrup.

fields.name: Turkey Dressing
fields.title: Grandma Scribbler's Turkey Stuffing
fields.description: A classic turkey stuffing recipe with bread, celery, and butter.
instructions: Pack body cavity of a crop negro lightly with dressing.
notes: Recipe title 'Grandma Scribbler's Turkey Stuffing' was extrapolated from the provided text.

The instruction 'Pack body cavity of a crop negro lightly with dressing.' is a direct transcription from the OCR text, and requires review for potential OCR errors or adjustments for clarity and cultural sensitivity.
fields.comment: Stuffing, or dressing, is a popular dish served with roasted turkey, chicken, or other poultry.  Its origins can be traced back to ancient Roman times, and recipes have evolved significantly across cultures and throughout history. Today, variations include ingredients like sausage, oysters, chestnuts, dried fruits, and herbs.

fields.name: Lemon Cake Pudding
fields.title: Lemon Cake Pudding
fields.description: A light and refreshing lemon-flavored cake pudding baked in a water bath.
instructions: Combine flour and salt.
Mix with lemon.
Blend together until light.
Mix well.
Fold in stiffly beaten egg whites.
Pour into buttered baking dish (glass casserole).
Set in pan of water having water reach about 1 inch up on dish.
Bake  30 to 40 min at 350 degrees. Use size of dish 8 and 9 inches in diameter.

fields.name: Frosted Chocolate Drops
fields.title: Frosted Chocolate Drops
fields.description: Chocolate drop cookies frosted with a soft chocolate frosting.
ingredients: 1 teaspoon Arm & Hammer or Cow Brand Baking Soda
instructions: Sift then measure the flour. Sift three times with the baking soda and salt.
Cream the butter until light and lemon colored. Add sugar gradually, beating after each addition.
Slowly add the well beaten egg, then the melted and cooled chocolate.
Stir vanilla into the milk. Alternately add dry ingredients and liquid, beating until smooth after each addition. Stir in nutmeats.
Drop by spoonfuls on ungreased baking sheet. Bake in hot oven.
When cool, frost with Soft Chocolate Frosting.

fields.name: Chocolate Chiparoons
fields.title: Chocolate Chipparoons
fields.description: A delicious drop cookie made with chocolate chips, coconut, and nuts.
ingredients: ½ cup brown sugar, firmly packed
instructions: Cream together the shortening, white and dark sugar, and vanilla until light and fluffy.
Fold in the egg and beat.
Sift together the flour, soda, and salt. Add to the first mixture.
Stir in Chipits and nuts and mix thoroughly.
Then stir coconut into the mixture.
Drop by spoonsful on a pan, well apart, and press each mound together with fingers.
Bake at 350°F for 8 minutes.
Remove from pan while hot, using a broad spatula.
fields.comment: Chipits were first introduced by the Canadian company, Nestle, in 1937 as a semi-sweet chocolate baking chip. They have become an essential pantry item for many home bakers in Canada and are still popular for making cookies.

fields.name: Chipits Oatmeal Cookies
fields.title: Chipits Oatmeal Cookies
fields.description: A classic oatmeal cookie recipe featuring chocolate chips.
ingredients: 1 3/4 cups once-sifted pastry flour (OR 1 3/4 cups once-sifted hard-wheat flour)
instructions: Sift together the flour and salt; mix in rolled oats and coconut.
Cream the shortening and gradually blend in brown sugar; cream well.
Dissolve the baking soda in boiling water; gradually stir into creamed mixture.
Mix in vanilla.
Add flour mixture, part at a time, mixing well after each addition.
Gently stir in the Chipits.

Drop dough by small spoonfuls, well apart, onto greased cookie pans and flatten each mound well with a fork which has been dipped into cold water -or chill dough about 1/2 hour, roll into small balls, arrange on greased cookie pans and press flat with a wet fork.
Bake in moderate oven, 350° for 12 to 15 minutes.
fields.comment: This recipe highlights the use of Chipits, a specific brand of chocolate chips, emphasizing their importance to the recipe's outcome.  This suggests a period of advertising and brand promotion within the food industry.

fields.name: Refrigerator Rolls
fields.title: Refrigerator Roll
fields.description: A simple, make-ahead roll recipe.
ingredients: Butter, the size of a walnut
Enough powdered sugar to spread and prevent sticking
instructions: Combine brown sugar, white sugar, and egg.
Mix in pastry flour, baking soda, and salt.
Add milk and mix until just combined.
Divide dough into three portions, roll into logs, wrap in wax paper, and chill.
To make the never-fail icing, combine brown sugar, thick cream, butter, and vanilla.
Heat until it bubbles slightly.
Slice the chilled dough and bake at 400°F (200°C).
Spread icing on warm rolls and dust with powdered sugar.

fields.name: Date Nut Bread
fields.title: Date Nut Bread
fields.description: A delicious loaf of date nut bread made with brown sugar, dates, walnuts, and spices.
instructions: Mix sugar, butter thoroughly.
Drop in whole egg and beat until creamy.
Sprinkle soda over dates, cut in small pieces, pour hot water over.
Let stand while breaking up nuts.
Add date mixture to sugar, egg, and butter mixture.
Add flour, nuts, vanilla and salt.
Bake for one hour in 350°F oven in well-greased loaf pan.
fields.comment: Date nut bread has been a popular treat since the early 20th century, often made with readily available ingredients like dates and nuts.  It's a moist, flavorful bread perfect for breakfast, snacks, or dessert.

fields.name: Date Loaf Bread
fields.title: Plate Loaf Bread
fields.description: A simple loaf bread made with dates, brown sugar, and nuts.
instructions: Pour boiling water over dates and let stand.
Mix together brown sugar, butter/Crisco, nut meats, flour, and egg.
Add the date mixture to the dry ingredients.
Mix thoroughly.
Bake in a loaf pan at 325°.
notes: The amount of soda is not specified in the OCR text and therefore was left out.
The OCR text mentions "lightly beaten" for an ingredient or step. This is not specifically given to an ingredient and therefore was left out.
fields.comment: Date loaf or date bread was particularly popular during the era of rationing in World War II, as dates were a readily available and nutritious sweetener when sugar was scarce.  It remains a classic comfort food enjoyed today.

fields.name: Diabetic Mayonaise
fields.title: Diabetic Mayonnaise
fields.description: A sugar-free mayonnaise recipe suitable for diabetics.
instructions: Juice lemon.
Add salt, dry mustard, and egg yolk to lemon juice.
Gradually add oil and whisk until emulsified.
fields.comment: Traditional mayonnaise recipes use a small amount of sugar or corn syrup to stabilize the emulsion and enhance flavor.  Diabetic versions typically omit the sugar and rely solely on the emulsifying properties of the egg yolk and careful whisking to create a stable mayonnaise.

fields.name: Buttermilk Pineapple Sherbet, Orange Quench and Chocolate Milk Shake
fields.title: Summer Recipes: Buttermilk Pineapple Sherbet, Orange Quench, and Chocolate Milk Shake
fields.description: Three refreshing summer recipes featuring buttermilk, pineapple, orange, and chocolate.

Buttermilk Pineapple Sherbet: Mix buttermilk, pineapple, and sugar until dissolved.
When it begins to set, stir from sides and bottom.
Sets in 4-5 hours. Stirring every 30 minutes improves texture, but once is sufficient.

Orange Quench: Combine milk, sugar, and orange juice.

Chocolate Milk Shake: Combine chocolate, salt, cream, milk, butter, brown sugar, and granulated sugar.
Cook slowly, stirring constantly for 5 minutes.
For the shake, use 2 tablespoons chocolate sauce, 2 tablespoons cream, and ¼ cup milk.

Orange Quench: Variation: Add ¼ teaspoon cinnamon for Spiced Orange Milk.

Chocolate Milk Shake: Variation: Chocolate Egg Nog: Add 1 egg, beat until fluffy.
Variation: Spiced Chocolate Milk: Add ½ teaspoon cinnamon.

fields.comment: These recipes showcase classic summer flavors and simple preparation methods. The variations offer customization options, highlighting the versatility of these base recipes.

fields.name: Cloverleaf Mik Ad, The Foundation Of Your Hot Weather Diet
fields.title: Clover Leaf Milk-Based Diet
fields.description: A cost-effective and nutritious diet plan centered around Clover Leaf Milk.
instructions: Incorporate Clover Leaf Milk into your daily diet by drinking it and using it in cooking.
fields.comment: This advertisement highlights the nutritional and economic benefits of Clover Leaf Milk, emphasizing its vitamin D fortification through irradiation, a common practice in the past.

fields.name: Mint Grape Frosting
fields.title: Mint Grape Frost
fields.description: A refreshing blend of mint, grape juice, and ginger ale.
instructions: Combine ice water and mint leaves in a pitcher.
Let stand until cool and mint flavor infuses the water.
Add simple syrup, grape juice, and ginger ale.
Chill thoroughly.
Serve well-chilled in frosted glasses.
Garnish with sprigs of mint.

fields.name: Coconut Pudding
fields.title: Coconut Pudding
fields.description: A creamy coconut pudding baked with raisins and a hint of bread flavoring.
instructions: Beat eggs, add sugar, milk & butter.
Add coconut, bread, flavoring and raisins.
Bake at about 300 until firm.
Serve cold.

fields.name: Butter Cookies
fields.title: Cookie Marie Ward
fields.description: A simple cookie recipe featuring butter, sugar, and vanilla.
instructions: Cream together butter and sugar thoroughly.
Add egg and vanilla.
Mix well.
Bake at 375°F (190°C) for 10-12 minutes.
notes: Added a large egg to bind and create structure for the cookies.
Included baking temperature and time which is common for most cookies
Adjusted 'Legge flance' to 'Large egg' for clarity.
Adjusted '3 cilps' to '1 tsp vanilla', assuming a typo and based on common cookie recipes.
fields.comment: This recipe seems to be a simplified version of classic sugar cookies. The name 'Cookie Marie Ward' suggests it might be a family recipe or named after someone. Sugar cookies have a long history, dating back to the 1700s in Nazareth, Pennsylvania.

fields.name: Date Pudding
fields.title: Date Pudding
fields.description: A steamed or baked pudding featuring dates and nuts.
ingredients: 1 scant teaspoon baking soda dissolved in a little water
1 cup dates cut into pieces and soaked in 1 cup boiling water
instructions: Mix sugar with egg yolks.
Add melted butter.
Add dry ingredients (flour, baking powder, baking soda mixture, and salt) alternately with the date mixture (soaked dates and water).
Beat well.
Add nuts and vanilla.
Steam for about two hours or bake in a loaf pan in a moderate oven until done.
Serve hot with sauce.

fields.name: Two Egg Cake
fields.title: Two Egg Cake
fields.description: A classic two-egg cake made with simple ingredients.
instructions: Cream the butter and sugar until light and fluffy.
Add the egg yolks and beat well.
Sift together the flour, baking powder, and salt.
Add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients alternately with the milk.
Fold in the stiffly beaten egg whites.
Pour batter into a prepared pan and bake at 350°F until a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean.

fields.name: Fruit Salad Dressing
fields.title: Biling to Carlo
fields.description: A simple recipe with limited information, likely involving boiling and cream.
instructions: Add 1 (unit unspecified) of cream.
notes: Limited information extracted from the image. The title 'Biling to Carlo' suggests a dish being prepared for someone named Carlo. The OCR text is unclear about the exact ingredients and process.
fields.comment: The name 'Biling to Carlo' suggests a personalized dish.  Without further context, it's difficult to place this recipe within a specific culinary tradition.

fields.name: Marshmallow Loaf Splendid Food for Children
fields.title: Marshmallow Loaf
fields.description: A no-bake loaf made with marshmallows, graham cracker crumbs, dates, and nuts.
instructions: Pour milk over quartered marshmallows.
Add dates and nuts.
Add graham cracker crumbs and knead thoroughly.
Mold into a loaf shape.
Let stand for 12 hours.
Slice and serve with or without whipped cream.
fields.comment: This recipe highlights the historical use of marshmallows in no-bake desserts, showcasing a simple and quick treat.  The emphasis on purity and wholesomeness, along with the suggestion for children, reflects the marketing of marshmallows in the past.

fields.name: Pears, Peaches and Plum Mash
fields.title: Pears, Peaches and Plum Mash
instructions: mash
sugar to suit

fields.name: Harvard Beets - Tempt Children
fields.title: Harvard Beets
fields.description: A sweet and tangy beet dish made with Wesson Oil, vinegar, and a touch of sugar.
ingredients: 12 small cooked beets or 1 No. 2 can sliced beets
instructions: Mix sugar and cornstarch.
Add vinegar, Wesson Oil, and water and boil 5 minutes, stirring constantly.
Add beets; cover and simmer about 30 minutes.
fields.comment: This recipe highlights the use of Wesson Oil in a vegetable dish, reflecting the advertising trends of the time that promoted vegetable oil for various cooking applications.

fields.name: Wesson Vegetable Casserole
fields.title: Wesson Vegetable Casserole
fields.description: A simple vegetable casserole recipe featuring Wesson Oil for enhanced flavor and texture.
ingredients: 2 cups diced potatoes or potato balls
instructions: Slice onions and tomatoes about 1/2-inch thick and place in a two-quart casserole with potatoes, celery, and carrots.
Sprinkle salt, pepper, and paprika over vegetables, add Wesson Oil, cover and bake in a moderately hot oven (375° F.) 1-1/2 hours, or until tender.
fields.comment: This recipe highlights the use of Wesson Oil not just for salads but also for cooking hot vegetables, emphasizing its role in enhancing both flavor and texture. It reflects the advertising and culinary trends of the mid-20th century when vegetable oil was becoming a kitchen staple.

fields.name: Raisin Cupcakes
fields.title: Raisin Cup Cakes
fields.description: Spiced raisin cup cakes that can also be made into a loaf.
ingredients: 1 teaspoon baking soda dissolved in a bit of water
instructions: Cream sugar and Spry (or shortening).
Add beaten eggs.
Fold in raisins.
Dissolve baking soda in a bit of water and add lemon juice.
Sift dry ingredients 3 times.
Combine wet and dry ingredients and mix well.
Pour into greased or floured muffin tins.
Bake until golden. Alternatively, the batter can be made into a loaf cake.
fields.comment: Spry was a popular shortening brand in the mid-20th century.  Cup cakes were often baked in specialized tins with individual compartments, giving rise to their name.

fields.name: Note on Pellagra - An epidemic in the US in the early 1900's
fields.title: Dr. Joseph Goldberger's Pellagra Experiment (1915)
fields.description: A recipe representing the dietary experiment conducted by Dr. Joseph Goldberger in 1915 to demonstrate that pellagra was caused by a dietary deficiency.
instructions: Assemble a group of volunteer inmates at a prison (Mississippi State Penitentiary).
Provide a controlled diet primarily consisting of corn meal, molasses, flour, with limited amounts of meat, sweet potatoes, and other vegetables.

Maintain this diet for six months. Note:  This part of the "recipe" was about inducing pellagra through dietary restrictions. In a modern context, we'd be looking at how to prevent or cure it, by including nutrient rich foods.
Observe the development of pellagra symptoms in the volunteers (skin lesions, digestive issues, mental confusion).

Introduce foods rich in niacin (vitamin B3) into the diet, such as lean meats, poultry, fish, legumes and enriched grains. In 1915, the exact nutrient wasn't identified yet.  This step reflects our modern understanding of how to reverse the effects of the restricted diet.
Observe the remission of pellagra symptoms.
notes: This recipe represents a historical dietary experiment, not a recommendation for a healthy diet. It highlights the importance of nutritional deficiencies in causing diseases like pellagra.  Pellagra is caused by a severe lack of niacin (vitamin B3).
fields.comment: Dr. Joseph Goldberger's work was crucial in understanding the nutritional basis of pellagra, a disease that was prevalent in the southern United States in the early 20th century. His experiment, though controversial by today’s standards, demonstrated that pellagra was not contagious, but rather caused by a dietary deficiency. The inclusion of niacin-rich foods in the diet eventually led to the eradication of pellagra as a major public health problem.

fields.name: Calender - Misc in Recipe collection
fields.title: August 1947 Calendar
fields.description: A calendar view of the month of August 1947.
fields.comment: This calendar page is a historical snapshot of August 1947, potentially from a personal diary, wall calendar, or newspaper.  It offers a glimpse into the days and weeks of this particular month, 76 years ago.  The simple layout and inclusion of adjacent months (July and September) suggest a practical, everyday use.

fields.name: Wesson Waffles
fields.title: Wesson Waffles
fields.description: Crispy waffles made quickly using Wesson Oil.
instructions: Beat egg yolks with milk and Wesson Oil.
Sift flour, baking powder, salt, and sugar together and stir into liquid, mixing just enough to make a smooth batter.
Fold in stiffly beaten egg whites.
Bake on a hot waffle iron.
Serve hot with honey, jam, cane, maple or corn syrup.
fields.comment: Wesson Oil's convenient liquid form eliminated the need to melt solid shortening, making waffle preparation faster.  This recipe reflects the mid-20th century trend of using readily available, processed ingredients for ease and speed in cooking.

fields.name: Wesson Fruit Cake
fields.title: Wesson Oil Fruit Cake
fields.description: A rich and mellow fruit cake made with Wesson Oil.
instructions: Combine Wesson Oil, sugar, and egg yolks and beat until well blended.
Sift spices, baking powder, salt and 2 cups of the flour together and add to sugar mixture alternately with the fruit juice.
Add remaining cup of flour to fruit and nuts and stir into batter.
Fold in stiffly beaten egg whites.
Brush 4 one-pound loaf pans or 1 large pan with Wesson Oil and line with thin brown paper brushed with oil.
Fill 2/3 full and bake in a slow oven (275° F.) 3 to 3-1/2 hours for the small cakes and 4 hours for the large cake.
fields.comment: This fruit cake recipe was popularized through advertisements for Wesson Oil, highlighting its use in baking for achieving rich and moist results.

fields.name: Cottage Cheese Recipes
fields.title: Cucumber Ring Salad
fields.description: A refreshing salad featuring a creamy cottage cheese mold surrounded by crisp cucumber rings.
instructions: Soak gelatin in cold water for five minutes then dissolve.
Put cheese through a sieve, add gelatin, mix until light and fluffy and combine with stiffly beaten cream.
Put in mold and place in refrigerator until set.
Peel cucumbers and slice in slices one-fourth inch thick.
Remove centers from cucumbers with a thimble or small knife.
Place cucumber rings in ice water until crisp.
When ready to serve arrange watercress on serving plate, place molded cheese mixture on bed of watercress and garnish with row of cucumber rings.
Serve with French dressing.

fields.name: Buttermilk Recipes
fields.title: Gingerbread and Griddle Cakes
fields.description: Recipes for gingerbread and griddle cakes using buttermilk.

Gingerbread: Cream butter and sugar. Add egg yolks. Add 1 teaspoon soda to molasses and one to buttermilk. Add molasses to mixture. Sift flour and spices and add alternately with buttermilk. Fold in the stiffly beaten egg whites. Bake at 350°.

Griddle Cakes: Mix buttermilk with sweet milk, well-beaten egg, soda, and salt. Add melted butter, cornmeal and sift in flour. Beat thoroughly. Drop by spoonful on griddle which has been greased with a bit of bacon fat. When full of bubbles and cooked on the edges turn on the other side. Delicious served with butter and maple syrup or jelly.

Buttermilk Dressing for Salads: Fold all the ingredients into the unbeaten buttermilk.
This dressing is delicious with a Waldorf salad made from fresh cabbage, apples, lettuce, and finely cut, fresh, uncooked spinach.
It is also a refreshing dressing for a salad made of green peppers, tomatoes, chopped celery, parsley and diced cucumbers. It can be used on many other vegetable salads as well.

fields.name: Fudge Squares
fields.title: Judge Squares
fields.description: A layered dessert bar with a chocolate and nut base, topped with a meringue-like frosting.
instructions: Cream together butter and sugar.
Add egg yolks and beat well.
Combine melted chocolate, flour, and milk. Add this mixture to the butter-sugar-egg mixture and beat until smooth.
Fold in chopped nuts.
In a separate bowl, beat egg whites until stiff peaks form.
Fold the beaten egg whites into the batter.
Bake in a moderate oven (350°F) for about 25 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean.
fields.comment: While the origin of Judge Squares is unknown, similar recipes like 'Blondies' and 'Brownies' have roots dating back to the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The combination of chocolate, nuts, and a meringue-like topping was likely influenced by European dessert traditions.

fields.name: Icebox Cookies
fields.title: Lee Box Cookies
fields.description: A simple yet delicious refrigerator cookie recipe.
instructions: Mix ingredients together in the order given, sifting dry ingredients before adding.
Press firmly into loaf pans.
Stand in the refrigerator for 12 hours or longer.
Slice very thin.
Bake in a hot oven.
fields.comment: Refrigerator cookies like these were popular during the mid-20th century as they allowed for baking fresh cookies on demand.

fields.name: Chocolate Cake
fields.title: CHOCOLATE CAKE
fields.description: A classic chocolate cake recipe.
instructions: Melt half of the butter and chocolate together.
Add boiling water and soda last.

fields.name: Rice Crispies Corn Flakes with Butter and Sugar
fields.title: Brown Sugar Brittle
fields.description: A simple dessert made with brown sugar and crispie treats poured over a bed of cauliflower or rice crispies.
instructions: Bring brown sugar and butter to baking stage.
Pour into greased bowl over the cauliflower or rice crispies.
Mix well and chill.
fields.comment: Brittles are a type of confectionery made by heating sugar and other ingredients to the 'hard crack' stage, resulting in a hard, glassy texture. The addition of crispie treats gives this brittle a playful twist.

fields.name: Graham Cracker Pie Crust
fields.title: Graham Cracker Crust
fields.description: A simple recipe for a graham cracker crust.
instructions: Crush the graham crackers.
Mix with shortening.
fields.comment: Graham cracker crusts are a popular base for many desserts, especially cheesecakes and pies. The combination of crushed graham crackers and shortening creates a buttery, crunchy crust that complements the creamy filling. This simple recipe provides a basic foundation that can be adapted with various flavorings like cinnamon or sugar.

fields.name: Bread And Butter Pickles
fields.title: Bread and Butter Pickles
fields.description: Sweet and tangy bread and butter pickles.
instructions: Combine sugar, vinegar, onion, salt, mustard seeds, ginger, and turmeric in a saucepan with water.
Bring to a boil, stirring until sugar and salt dissolve.
Pack cucumbers into sterilized jars.
Pour hot pickling liquid over cucumbers, leaving 1/2 inch headspace.
Remove air bubbles and wipe jar rims.
Seal with lids and rings.
Process in a boiling water bath for 10 minutes.
Let cool and store in a cool, dark place for at least 24 hours before enjoying.
fields.comment: Bread and butter pickles gained popularity during the Great Depression, offering a way to preserve excess cucumbers while adding a tangy, sweet flavor to meals, often alongside bread and butter sandwiches during lean times. They remain a popular condiment today.

fields.name: Boiled Fruit Cake
fields.title: Boiled Fruit Cake
fields.description: A rich, moist fruit cake made with boiled sugar, spices, and raisins.
instructions: Boil sugar, shortening, water, cinnamon, cloves, salt, and cocoa together.
Add raisins.
Add flour and baking soda. Mix well.
Bake according to desired recipe instructions.
notes: The original text was unclear about baking instructions. Please refer to a standard fruitcake recipe for baking times and temperatures.
Instructions for "hula-heel" were unclear and were omitted.  If you intend to add a hula-heel, you'll need to find instructions elsewhere.
fields.comment: Boiled fruit cakes represent an older style of fruit cake making, where the ingredients are literally boiled together to create a dense, moist cake.

fields.name: Candy Apples
fields.title: Big Red Apples
fields.description: Candied apples coated in a vibrant red syrup.
instructions: Combine sugar, corn syrup, and water in a deep pan.
Cook over low heat until the mixture reaches a deep red color.
Add food coloring (optional).
Insert wooden sticks into apples.
Coat apples with the red syrup and serve.
fields.comment: Candied apples, also known as toffee apples outside of North America, are a popular treat, especially around holidays like Halloween.  Their vibrant color and sweet, crunchy coating make them a favorite among children and adults alike.

fields.name: Popcorn Balls
fields.title: Papi Com Halls
fields.description: A simple candy recipe made with sugar, corn syrup, butter, and water.
ingredients: 1/2 cup light corn syrup (either white or dark)
instructions: Combine sugar, corn syrup, and water in a saucepan over medium heat.
Stir until sugar dissolves, then bring to a boil without stirring.
Continue boiling until the mixture reaches a hard-ball stage (250-265°F on a candy thermometer or forms a hard ball when dropped in cold water).
Remove from heat and stir in butter until melted.
Pour onto a buttered surface or into buttered molds and let cool completely.
Break into pieces or remove from molds once cooled.
fields.comment: This recipe seems to be a variation on a classic hard candy recipe. The name "Papi Com Halls" suggests a personal or regional name, adding a touch of nostalgia.  Hard candies like this have been popular for centuries, enjoyed for their sweet taste and long shelf life.  The use of corn syrup helps prevent crystallization, resulting in a smooth, glassy candy.

fields.name: Meat Sauce
fields.title: Meat Sauce
fields.description: A sweet and savory sauce made with tomatoes, onions, apples, and spices.
instructions: Chop tomatoes, onions, and apples together.
Add vinegar, sugar, mustard, salt, allspice, and cloves.
Boil for 1 hour.
Seal in sterilized jars.

fields.name: Dill Pickles
fields.title: Dill Pickles
fields.description: A simple recipe for dill pickles using vinegar, salt, alum, and spices.
instructions: Boil all ingredients together.
fields.comment: Pickling is a method of preserving food that dates back thousands of years.  Dill pickles remain a popular snack and condiment.

fields.name: Sweet Pickles
fields.title: Sweet Pickles
fields.description: Sweet pickles made with a strong salt brine and a vinegar, sugar, and spice syrup.
ingredients: Lumps of alum (size of a walnut)
instructions: Soak pickles in a strong salt brine for 1 week.
Drain the brine and rinse off the pickles with boiling water.
Let stand for 24 hours.
Drain, cover with boiling water to which lumps of alum the size of a walnut have been added.
Let stand 24 hours, drain.
Cover with boiling water, drain, and bring a syrup made from 2 1/2 cups white vinegar, 1 tablespoon celery seed, 2 cups sugar, and mixed pickling spices to a boil.
Pour the boiling syrup over the pickles and let stand 24 hours.
Heat syrup to boiling point and add pickles. Repeat each day until 8 cups of sugar have been used.

fields.name: Carrot Plum Pudding
fields.title: Carrot Plum Pudding
fields.description: A spiced steamed pudding featuring carrots, plums, and apples.

meta.Total Time: 2 hours steaming or 50 minutes pressure cooking

instructions: Steam in greased baking powder mold or double boiler for 2 hours or cook 50 minutes at 15 lbs. pressure in pressure cooker.

fields.name: Chili Sauce
fields.title: Chili Sauce
fields.description: A sweet and spicy chili sauce made with ripe tomatoes, onions, and a blend of spices.
instructions: Boil all ingredients for 2 hours, or until the sauce has thickened.
Seal in sterilized jars.
fields.comment: Canning and preserving were especially popular during the 19th and early 20th centuries before refrigeration was common.  This recipe reflects that tradition.

fields.name: Frozen Cheese Salad
fields.title: Frozen Cheese Salad
fields.description: A refreshing frozen salad made with cottage cheese, whipped cream, olives, and pimientos.
instructions: Mix the cottage cheese with the whipped cream.
Add the chopped green olives and pimientos.
Stir in the lemon juice.
Season with salt and cayenne pepper.
Mix thoroughly.
Pack the mixture into a wet mold.
Freeze for four hours.
Unmold and serve on lettuce.
notes: Royal Crest dry cottage cheese can be ordered in advance through your driver for 10 cents per jar.
fields.comment: Cottage cheese salads, both sweet and savory, were popular throughout the 20th century.  Frozen versions offered a cool and refreshing treat, especially during warmer months.

fields.name: Cupcakes
fields.title: Cup Cakes
fields.description: A classic recipe for delicious cup cakes.
instructions: Sift flour once, measure, baking powder, and sift together three times.
Cream butter thoroughly, add sugar gradually, and cream together until light and fluffy.
Add eggs, then flour, alternately with milk, a small amount at a time. Beat after each addition until smooth.
Add flavoring.
Pour into greased muffin pans, filling each about 2/3 full.
Bake in a moderate oven (350°F) for 20-25 minutes.
fields.comment: Cupcakes have been a popular treat since the 19th century, offering a delightful individual-sized portion of cake.

fields.name: Lemon Ice Box Cake
fields.title: Lemon Dee Box Cake
fields.description: A layered dessert featuring a lemon custard, whipped cream, and vanilla wafers.
instructions: Dissolve gelatin in cold water.
Beat 4 egg yolks with 1 cup sugar until thick.
Add lemon juice and zest. Cook in a double boiler until thick.
Add the cooled gelatin to the lemon mixture.
Beat 8 egg whites and gradually add 1/2 cup sugar.
Fold the egg white mixture into the lemon custard mixture.
Fold in the whipped cream.
Line a box or mold with wax paper.
Layer vanilla wafers and the lemon custard mixture as desired.

fields.name: Bread And Butter Pickles
fields.title: Bread & Butter Pickles
fields.description: Sweet and tangy pickles made with cucumbers and onions.
instructions: Slice cucumbers and onions thinly.
Soak cucumbers in salt water (1/2 cup salt per gallon of water). Rinse well.
Mix together vinegar, sugar, celery seed, turmeric, mustard, ginger, and pickling spice.
Bring mixture to a boil.
Pour over cucumbers and onions.
Boil for 20 minutes.
Sterilize jars and lids.
Pack pickles into jars, leaving headspace.
Pour hot pickling liquid over pickles, covering completely.
Remove air bubbles.
Wipe jar rims and seal with lids.
Process in a boiling water bath for 10 minutes.
notes: The original recipe mentions "fet pork" which seems to be a typo or an OCR error and is omitted here. Consider brining the pickles to maintain crispiness.
fields.comment: Bread and butter pickles originated in the early 20th century, possibly as a way to use excess cucumbers during the summer. Their sweet and tangy flavor profile contrasts with traditional dill pickles, offering a unique addition to sandwiches, burgers, and relish trays.

fields.name: Chocolate Syrup
fields.title: Chocolate Syrup
fields.description: A versatile chocolate syrup for drinks or dessert sauce.
instructions: Melt chocolate over hot water.
Add 1 cup hot water, 1 cup sugar, and 1/2 teaspoon salt.
Cook for about 5 minutes, stirring until smooth.
Cool and add vanilla.
Store in a covered glass jar in the refrigerator.
For chocolate drinks, use 2 tablespoons syrup per 1 cup milk.
For ice cream or other dessert sauces, reheat and add 1 tablespoon butter.

fields.name: August 1940 Dairy Order
fields.title: Dairy Products Price List
fields.description: A list of dairy product prices from August 10, 1940.
fields.comment: This price list offers a glimpse into the cost of dairy products during wartime.  The emphasis on "Vitamin 'D' Milk" suggests a growing awareness of nutritional value in food marketing.  The distinction between "Light" and "Heavy" cream likely refers to butterfat content.  The inclusion of cottage cheese highlights its place as a staple food item.

fields.name: Refrigerator Date Pin Wheels
fields.title: Refrigerator Date Wheels
fields.description: A sweet treat with dates, nuts, and a hint of cocoa, perfect for making ahead and storing in the refrigerator.
instructions: Combine sugar and water and boil until thick.
Add nuts to the sugar syrup.
Cream together shortening, brown sugar, and cocoa.
Add the egg and mix well.
Sift together flour, salt, and baking soda.
Add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients and mix well.
Divide the dough into 2 parts.
Roll each part into a rectangular shape about 1/4 inch thickness.
Spread with date paste and roll as for jelly roll.
Wrap in paper and let stand in the refrigerator overnight.
Cut into 1/2 inch slices and bake at 400°F oven until mildly brown.
fields.comment: Refrigerator cookies were popular during the mid-20th century as they offered a convenient way to have fresh-baked cookies without much fuss on the day of serving.  These date-filled cookies are a delicious example.

fields.name: Pear Salad
fields.title: Pear Salad
fields.description: A molded pear salad with a creamy, cheesy topping.
ingredients: Water (enough to make 2 cups with pear juice)
instructions: Drain the pears, reserving the juice.
Add water to the pear juice to make 2 cups total liquid.
In a saucepan, combine the pear juice mixture, sugar, and salt. Heat the mixture.
In a separate bowl, sprinkle the gelatin over enough cold water to cover and let it soften.
Add the softened gelatin to the warm pear juice mixture. Cook just long enough to dissolve the gelatin completely.
Stir in the vinegar.
Arrange the drained pear halves upside down in a shallow pan or dish.
Pour the gelatin mixture over the pears.
In a bowl, whip the double cream until soft peaks form.
Fold the mayonnaise into the whipped cream.
Once the pear-gelatin mixture is cold but not yet congealed, spread the whipped cream and mayonnaise mixture over the top.
Sprinkle the grated cheese over the cream layer.
Refrigerate for at least 12 hours before serving.
Cut into squares and serve on lettuce leaves.

fields.name: Tomato Catsup
fields.title: Tomato Catsup (Mrs. Wright)
fields.description: A classic tomato catsup recipe from Mrs. Wright.
instructions: Chop tomatoes and onions and cook until tender.
Mix together and strain through a colander.
Add vinegar, brown sugar, white sugar, and salt.
Tie spices (celery seed, cloves, allspice, ginger, and dry mustard) in a muslin bag and boil with the tomato mixture.
Boil all together until it reaches the right consistency.
Seal.

fields.name: Fruit Salad Dressing
fields.title: Fruit Salad Dressing
fields.description: A creamy dressing for fruit salad made with butter, sugar, eggs, lemon juice, and whipped cream.
ingredients: 1 bottle stiffly whipped ROYAL CREST double cream
instructions: Cook butter, sugar, and egg yolks in a double boiler, stirring constantly.
Cool the mixture.
Fold in the whipped cream.
fields.comment: This recipe highlights a classic approach to fruit salad dressings before the widespread use of commercial mayonnaise or yogurt-based dressings.  The use of a double boiler demonstrates a careful cooking technique to prevent the eggs from curdling.

fields.name: Meatballs
fields.title: Meatballs
fields.description: Simple meatballs made with hamburger, flour, rice, egg, tomato paste, and water.
instructions: Mix hamburger, flour, rice, egg, salt, and pepper.
Form into small balls.
Mix tomato paste and water in a pot and bring to a boil.
Add meatballs to the boiling soup.
Simmer until tender.
notes: Added salt and pepper to the ingredients list based on typical meatball recipes.
fields.comment: Meatballs are a globally popular dish with numerous variations. This recipe appears to be a simplified version of a classic tomato-based meatball soup.

fields.name: Cloverleaf Strawberry Recipes
fields.title: Clover Leaf Strawberry Ice Box Cake
fields.description: A no-bake cake made with layers of Nabisco crumbs, sweet cream butter mixture, strawberries, and whipped cream.
ingredients: 3/4 cup Clover Leaf sweet cream butter
instructions: Grind Nabisco cookies in a food chopper.
Arrange half of the crumbs in the bottom of a pan.
Cream together powdered sugar and butter.
Add beaten eggs to the butter mixture and spread over the crumbs.
Cut strawberries in half and arrange over the cream layer.
Whip the cream and spread over the berries.
Top with remaining crumbs.
Chill in refrigerator for 24 hours before serving.
fields.comment: Icebox cakes were popular in the early to mid-20th century, particularly during the summer months before widespread air conditioning.  They rely on the chilling process to meld flavors and soften ingredients like cookies or wafers into a cake-like consistency.

fields.name: Cloverleaf Summer Diet
fields.title: Dairy Foods in Summer
fields.description: Embrace the economy and health benefits of dairy foods year-round, especially in summer with refreshing options like Clover Leaf Creamed Cottage Cheese and Clover Leaf Buttermilk.
instructions: Use dairy products liberally year-round.
Enjoy Clover Leaf Creamed Cottage Cheese in summer salads.
Serve cold Clover Leaf Buttermilk as a refreshing beverage or use it in recipes.
Use the cream from Irradiated Clover Leaf Milk for berries, fruits, cereals, or whipping.
fields.comment: This advertisement highlights the historical context of promoting dairy as a healthy and economical food choice, particularly during summer.  It emphasizes the perceived benefits of dairy as non-fattening and non-heating while still providing essential nutrients.  The focus on specific brands like Clover Leaf and the mention of 'irradiated vitamin D milk' reflect the trends and technological advancements in food processing and marketing during that era.

fields.name: Hard Soap
fields.title: Hard Soaps
fields.description: A recipe for making hard soaps using grease, lye, and other ingredients.
instructions: Dissolve lye in one quart of cold water.
Strain grease and let cool to lukewarm.
Add perfume (1 ounce per batch).
Read lye can directions for further assistance.
fields.comment: Historically, soap-making was a common household chore, utilizing readily available animal fats and lye. Today, while commercially produced soaps dominate the market, traditional soap-making remains a craft enjoyed by many.

fields.name: Date And Nut Bread
fields.title: Date and Nut Bread
fields.description: A moist and delicious bread made with dates and nuts.
instructions: Pour boiling water over dates and let stand while mixing other ingredients.
Mix sugar, egg, shortening, and dates.
Add flour, salt, vanilla and nutmeats.
Mix well and pour into a loaf pan.
Bake at 325°F for 1 1/2 hours.

fields.name: Bread Butter Pickle
fields.title: Bread and Butter Pickles
fields.description: Sweet and tangy pickles made with cucumbers, onions, peppers, and a blend of spices.
instructions: Slice cucumbers and onions.
Sprinkle with salt and let stand in ice cubes about 3 hours.
Drain well.
Boil in vinegar and spices for 10 minutes.

fields.name: Ruby Marlow With Red Cherries
fields.title: Ruby Marlow with Red Cherries
fields.description: A frozen dessert made with marshmallows, cherries, and nuts.
instructions: Heat 25 marshmallows and milk in a double boiler until marshmallows are melted, stirring occasionally. Add salt and cool.
Pour mixture into an automatic refrigerator tray and chill in the freezing unit until it begins to thicken.
Whip cream and add vanilla extract. Fold into the marshmallow mixture.
Add cherries, nut meats, and the remaining 15 marshmallows (cut into small pieces with wet scissor blades).
Return to the freezing unit and set the control to the coldest point to freeze.
When the mixture becomes mushy, stir 3 times with a fork at 15-minute intervals.
Once frozen, turn the control back to a temperature slightly colder than ordinarily maintained and let it ripen for several hours.
notes: Brighten cherry color by adding ½ teaspoon red vegetable coloring to cherries and juice, let stand 30 minutes, then drain.

fields.name: Southern Fried Chicken
fields.title: Southern Fried Chicken
fields.description: Classic Southern Fried Chicken recipe using Wesson Oil for a wholesome, digestible fry.
ingredients: 1 cup thin cream or cold water (for gravy, optional)
instructions: Cut the chicken into about 12 pieces.
Season flour with salt and pepper.
Beat egg and water together.
Roll each chicken piece in seasoned flour, then in the egg mixture, then in bread crumbs.
Heat 1/2 inch of Wesson Oil in a skillet.
Place chicken pieces in hot oil, cover, and cook slowly for about 1 hour, turning often to brown evenly.
Drain the chicken and transfer to a hot platter.
For gravy (optional): Add equal amount of flour to the remaining fat, blend, and stir in cream or water. Season with salt and pepper.
fields.comment: This recipe highlights the use of Wesson Oil, emphasizing its high smoke point and ability to produce light, digestible fried food. This reflects the advertising trends of the time, focusing on health benefits alongside taste.

fields.name: Wesson Donuts
fields.title: Wesson Doughnuts
fields.description: Light and digestible doughnuts fried in Wesson Oil.
instructions: Mix Wesson Oil, sugar and eggs, beating thoroughly.
Sift flour, baking powder, soda, spices, and salt together and add to first mixture alternately with the sour milk, mixing to a smooth dough.
Chill for 20 minutes.
Place dough, a portion at a time, on a slightly floured board and roll out 1/4 inch thick.
Cut with a doughnut cutter dipped in flour.
Fry until a delicate brown in hot deep Wesson Oil (365° to 375° F.) or hot enough to brown a one-inch cube of bread in 60 seconds.
Drain on absorbent paper, cool, and sprinkle with sugar.
fields.comment: This recipe highlights the historical use of Wesson Oil for frying, emphasizing its high smoke point.  It reflects a time when specific brands were frequently featured in recipes.

fields.name: Pumpkin Cream Pie
fields.title: Punkin Cream Pie
fields.description: A creamy pumpkin pie made with evaporated milk and spices.
instructions: Mix together cornstarch and sugar.
Add nutmeg, ginger, and cloves.
In a separate bowl, whisk together evaporated milk, pumpkin puree, and egg yolks.
Cook in a double boiler until thickened.
Beat the egg yolks and stir the thickened mixture slowly into the eggs. Return to the double boiler and heat again.
Pour into a pie crust and bake until set.
notes: The original text did not mention using a pie crust nor how to cook the filling. This is implied.
fields.comment: Pumpkin pie, often called punkin pie in older recipes, has been a beloved dessert in America since colonial times. Cream pies, including pumpkin, gained popularity in the 19th century with the advent of canned evaporated milk, making them easier to prepare.

fields.name: Dressing Stuffing
fields.title: Dressing
fields.description: A savory bread dressing made with toasted sundry bread, onion, poultry seasoning, celery, butter, and eggs, moistened with hot water.
instructions: Mix together bread, onion, poultry seasoning, salt, celery, butter, and beaten eggs.
Add enough hot water to moisten slightly.
notes: Can be made without eggs.

fields.name: Salad Dressing
fields.title: Salad Dressing
fields.description: A flavorful salad dressing made with a blend of spices, sauces, and oil.
instructions: Combine all ingredients and mix well.

fields.name: Silver White Cake
fields.title: Silver White Cake
fields.description: A delicate and tender white cake made with Softasilk flour and the Betty Crocker method.
ingredients: ½ cup High Grade Vegetable Shortening
¾ cup Egg Whites, unbeaten (4 large)
instructions: Sift together the flour, baking powder, and salt.
Add the sugar, shortening, ⅓ cup of milk, and flavoring.
Beat for 2 minutes.
Add the remaining milk and egg whites.
Beat for 2 minutes.
Grease and flour two 8-inch round cake pans.
Bake at 350° (moderate oven) for 30 to 35 minutes.
fields.comment: This recipe highlights the popularity of cake mixes and specific brands like Softasilk in the mid-20th century.  The emphasis on the "Betty Crocker Method" suggests the influence of Betty Crocker cookbooks and products on home baking practices during this time.

fields.name: Betty Crocker Soft As Silk Method
fields.title: Sensational New Cakes with Softasilk Method
fields.description: These cakes are quicker and easier to make with the new Softasilk method, resulting in fluffy and light cakes.
instructions: Set out all the ingredients 1 to 2 hours before mixing (less in hot weather) so they'll be at room temperature. Shortening and butter should be soft, not melted.
Turn on oven so it will be at right baking temperature when cake is ready for oven.
Prepare pans as specified in recipe.
Sift SOFTASILK Cake Flour before measuring.
Measure dry ingredients into sifter, and sift together into mixing bowl.
Measure shortening and liquid. Measure flavoring into liquid.
Add shortening and part or all of the liquid to the dry ingredients. (In some recipes, all the liquid, and in others, only 3/4 of the liquid is added at this point.)
Mix with an electric mixer on slow to medium speed or with a spoon for 2 minutes, scraping the sides and bottom of bowl constantly.
notes: No laborious creaming of shortening and sugar necessary!
No separate beating of eggs. All mixing in one bowl!
Fewer utensils used!
Mixing time cut by MORE THAN HALF!
You'll get the fluffiest, highest, lightest, BEST Cakes you ever made!
fields.comment: This recipe highlights the Softasilk method, a mid-20th century cake-making technique by Betty Crocker that emphasized convenience and speed. It reflects the trend of simplifying baking processes for the modern homemaker.

fields.name: Orange Loaf Cake
fields.title: SOFTASILK Orange Loaf Cake
fields.description: A refreshing orange-flavored loaf cake with a fine, close texture, similar to old-fashioned pound cakes but quicker and easier to make.
ingredients: 1½ tsp double-acting baking powder (Clabber Girl, Davis, Calumet, etc.)
1¾ tsp phosphate-type baking powder (Rumford, Dr. Price's, etc.)
½ cup high-grade vegetable shortening (part butter for flavor)
½ cup liquid (grated rind and juice from 1 medium orange + water)
instructions: Grease and line a 4x8-inch bread loaf pan with plain paper.
Sift together the flour, baking powder, salt, and sugar into a mixing bowl.
Place orange rind in a measuring cup, add juice, and then add enough water to make ½ cup.
Add the shortening and liquid to the dry ingredients.
Mix with an electric mixer on slow to medium speed (or beat with a spoon) for 2 minutes, scraping the bowl frequently.
Add the unbeaten eggs and continue mixing for another 2 minutes, scraping the bowl frequently. (Total mixing time: 4 minutes.)
Pour batter into the prepared pan and place it on an ungreased cookie sheet.
Bake in a moderate oven (350°F) for 60-65 minutes.
Let the cake stand in the pan for a moment before turning it onto a wire cooling rack.
notes: When mixing by hand, you can let the batter stand while you rest, but ensure the total mixing time is 4 minutes.
fields.comment: This recipe highlights the transition to more convenient baking methods while still valuing the qualities of traditional cakes.  The use of specific brand names for baking powder reflects the marketing landscape of the time and the importance of choosing the correct type for optimal results.

fields.name: AI Generated Recipe of Great Grandma's Favorite Cookie
fields.image: images/ruby/AI Generated Recipe of Great Grandma's Favorite Cookie.png
fields.title: 1940s Molasses and Ginger Cookies
fields.description: A recipe variant based on archival "Grandma's" and "Old-Fashioned" recipes from the 1940s, using molasses or syrup and common pantry staples.
ingredients: 1 cup shortening (such as Crisco or lard)
2 cups sugar (or a mix of 1 cup granulated and 1 cup brown sugar)
instructions: Cream the shortening and sugar: In a large bowl, use an electric mixer to cream together the shortening and sugar until the mixture is light and fluffy.
Add wet ingredients: Beat in the eggs, then add the molasses (or syrup) and mix until well combined.
Combine leaveners: Dissolve the baking soda in the sour milk and add this mixture to the creamed ingredients.
Add dry ingredients: In a separate bowl, sift together 4 cups of the flour with the ginger, cinnamon, nutmeg, and salt.
Mix the dough: Add the dry ingredients to the wet mixture in increments, mixing until a soft, uniform dough forms. The dough may be a bit sticky-add up to 1 more cup of flour if needed.
Chill the dough: Cover the dough and chill it in the refrigerator for at least one hour.
Preheat oven and prepare pans: Preheat your oven to 350°F (175°C). Grease a few cookie sheets or line them with parchment paper.

Bake the cookies: Drop the dough by rounded teaspoonfuls onto the prepared cookie sheets. Bake for 8 to 10 minutes, until the cookies are set but still soft. For a crispier cookie, bake for a couple of extra minutes.
Cool: Let the cookies cool on the baking sheet for a few minutes before transferring them to a wire rack to cool completely.
notes: To make your own sour milk, add 1 tablespoon of white vinegar or lemon juice to a measuring cup and fill the rest with milk. Let it stand for 5 minutes.
fields.comment: This type of molasses or ginger cookie was popular during the World War II era due to sugar rations, often utilizing sour milk and baking soda for leavening.

fields.name: Mystery Appetizer Solved Crab and Grapefruit Cocktail
fields.image: images/adds/Mystery Appetizer Solved Crab and Grapefruit Cocktail.png
fields.title: Canned Grapefruit-Canned Crabmeat Cocktail
fields.description: A retro-style, tart and savory seafood appetizer layered in glasses and topped with a homemade cocktail sauce.
instructions: Prepare the crab and grapefruit: Chill both the can of crabmeat and the can of grapefruit sections. Once chilled, drain the grapefruit thoroughly and flake the crabmeat, making sure to remove any small pieces of cartilage.
Make the sauce: In a separate bowl, whisk together the catsup, tomato juice, lemon juice, sugar, Worcestershire sauce, and salt until completely combined.
Assemble the cocktails: Layer the drained grapefruit sections and flaked crabmeat in cocktail glasses.
Serve: Pour the sauce over the layered ingredients and serve immediately.
fields.comment: This mid-century appetizer, popular in 1959, reflects a time when convenience foods like canned goods were becoming increasingly common in American kitchens.  The combination of sweet grapefruit, savory crab, and tangy cocktail sauce might seem unusual to modern palates, but it represents a unique flavor profile appreciated in its era.

fields.name: Mystery Solved No Knead Bread
fields.title: Mystery Solved No Knead Bread
fields.description: A no-knead bread recipe requiring minimal effort with ingredients like yeast, sugar, water, shortening, eggs, and flour.
ingredients: Wesson oil or other vegetable oil, for greasing bowls
instructions: In a large bowl, dissolve the yeast and a pinch of the sugar in 1/2 cup of warm water and let it sit for about 5 minutes, until it becomes foamy.
Add the remaining sugar, salt, melted shortening, 2 cups of warm water, and the beaten eggs. Stir well to combine.
Gradually add the flour, a cup at a time, until the dough is firm enough to pull away from the sides of the bowl. The dough will be soft and a bit sticky, not completely smooth.
Grease a separate bowl with Wesson oil. Place the dough inside and turn it over once to coat it in the oil.
Cover the bowl tightly with plastic wrap and refrigerate overnight or for up to 5 days.
An hour before baking, take out the amount of dough you need.
Shape it into a loaf or rolls and place in a greased loaf pan or on a baking sheet.
Let the dough rise for about 1 to 2 hours, or until it has doubled in bulk.
Preheat your oven to 400°F.
Bake for 10-15 minutes, or until golden brown.
notes: The amount of flour can vary depending on humidity. Add just enough to get a soft, workable dough without it being dry.
fields.comment: No-knead bread recipes gained popularity due to their convenience and ease of preparation.  This recipe attempts to recreate a "mystery" no-knead bread.

fields.name: Zesty Italian Chicken
fields.title: Zesty Italian Chicken
fields.description: Give chicken a lift with a flavorful, zesty Italian dressing mix.
instructions: Before broiling or roasting, brush chicken with a mixture of salad dressing mix, oil and water.

fields.name: Apricot Chicken (2)
fields.title: Apricot Chicken
fields.description: Chicken baked with a flavorful apricot, curry, and onion soup mix sauce.
ingredients: 2 frying chickens cut up or approximately 6-8 whole chicken breasts
1 pkg. (1 3/8 oz) dry onion soup mix
instructions: Wash and skin chicken. Pat dry.
Mix dressing, jam, curry powder and onion soup mix.
Pour over chicken.
Bake at 350 degrees for 1 hour and 15 min. (covered)
Good served over rice.

fields.name: Baked Beans
fields.title: Baked Beans
fields.description: A classic comfort food, these baked beans are slow-cooked with bacon, brown sugar, and a touch of mustard.
instructions: Brown the bacon.
Brown the onions in the bacon grease. Drain the grease.
Add brown sugar, catsup, and powdered mustard to the pot.
Crumble the bacon and add it to the pot along with the beans.
Bake at 350°F or less for 2 hours, stirring occasionally.
fields.comment: Baked beans have a rich history dating back to Native American cuisine.  Variations abound, with different regions and cultures adding their own unique twists to the basic recipe.  Today, baked beans remain a popular side dish, particularly in the United States and the United Kingdom, often accompanying barbecue dishes or enjoyed as part of a full English breakfast.

fields.name: Caramel Corn
fields.title: Caramel Corn
fields.description: A sweet and crunchy treat made with popped corn, brown sugar, butter, and Karo syrup.
instructions: Boil brown sugar, butter, Karo syrup, and cream of tartar for 5 to 7 minutes until it reaches the soft ball stage (227 degrees).
Pour the caramel mixture over the popped corn and stir to coat evenly.
Spread the caramel corn in a flat pan.
Bake at 250 degrees for 1 hour, stirring every 15 minutes.

fields.name: Chicken Breasts With Bacon
fields.title: Chicken Breasts with Bacon
fields.description: Chicken breast halves wrapped in bacon, baked in a creamy mushroom and sour cream sauce.
instructions: Wrap each chicken breast half in a slice of bacon.
Place the wrapped chicken breasts in a 9 x 13 inch pan.
In a bowl, mix together the sour cream and cream of mushroom soup.
Pour the sour cream mixture over the chicken in the pan.
Cover and bake for 3 hours at 300 degrees.

fields.name: Chicken Broccoli Rollups
fields.title: CHICKEN BROCCOLI ROLL-UPS
fields.description: Creamy chicken and broccoli filling wrapped in crispy philo dough, perfect as a snack or main course.
instructions: Cream the cheese and pepper.
Beat well.
Stir in chicken, mushrooms and broccoli.
Fold in thirds, then thirds again and then in half.
Put one ice cream scoop of mixture on pastry.
Bring four corners together and pinch to seal.
Dip in melted margarine and then in bread crumbs.
Place on ungreased cookie sheet.
Bake at 350 Degrees 20 minutes.
Can be frozen and used later. If so remove from freezer 2 hours before baking.
Make gravy from chicken broth and serve over top.

fields.name: Chicken Divan
fields.title: CHICKEN DIVAN
fields.description: A creamy casserole with chicken, broccoli, and a flavorful sauce.
ingredients: 5 whole chicken breasts, cooked and deboned
3 (10 oz) boxes of broccoli, cooked but not too much
instructions: Layer broccoli, then chicken in a baking dish.
Combine cream of chicken soup, lemon juice, mayonnaise, and curry powder.
Pour mixture over the chicken and broccoli.
Sprinkle with parmesan cheese and then paprika.
Bake at 350 degrees for 30-45 minutes.

fields.name: Chocolate Cookies (2)
fields.title: Chocolate Cookies
fields.description: Classic chocolate cookies made with simple ingredients.
instructions: Margarine, sugar, eggs til fluffy.
Add chocolate and vanilla and beat.
Add dry ingredients and milk alternately.
Chill well.
Roll in small balls and then in powdered sugar.
Grease cookie sheet.
Bake at 350 for 12 minutes.

fields.name: Curry Chicken
fields.title: Curry Chicken
fields.description: A simple curry chicken recipe made with Vermont Curry mix, chicken, carrots, potatoes, and onions.
instructions: Cut chicken, onions, carrots, potatoes into cubes.
Saute until golden brown.
Add 4 cups water and bring to boil.
Break curry sauce mix into pieces and add to sauce pan.
Cook over low heat about 20 minutes or until curry thickens.
Serve over cooked rice or noodles.

fields.name: Easy Chicken Oriental (typed)
fields.title: Easy Chicken Oriental
fields.description: A comforting casserole dish featuring chicken, vegetables, and a biscuit topping.
ingredients: 10 3/4 oz can cream of mushroom soup
1 1/2 cups cubed cooked chicken or 2 cans chunk white chicken
instructions: Preheat oven to 450 degrees F.
Rinse frozen pea pods under cold running water to separate and drain.
In a 3-quart saucepan, combine pea pods, soup, milk, chicken, green onions, celery, and water chestnuts.
Heat to boiling, stirring constantly. Reduce heat and keep warm.
In a separate bowl, mix Bisquick, 3 tbsp water, and soy sauce until a soft dough forms. Beat vigorously for 20 strokes.
Gently smooth the dough into a ball on a lightly floured board. Knead 5 times.
Roll the dough into a 5-inch square and cut into 1-inch squares.
Pour the chicken mixture into an ungreased 2-quart casserole dish.
Top with the dough squares.
Spread melted butter over the dough squares and sprinkle with sesame seeds.
Bake for about 15 minutes, or until golden brown.
fields.comment: This recipe reflects the Americanized "Oriental" cuisine popular in the mid-20th century.  It often combined convenience ingredients with flavors inspired by East Asian cuisine.

fields.name: Exotic Chicken Salad
fields.title: Exotic Chicken Salad
fields.description: A refreshing chicken salad with a blend of sweet and savory flavors.
ingredients: 4 Cups Chicken (cooked, boned and skinned) cubed
instructions: Mix the chicken, celery, water chestnuts, pineapple chunks, mandarin oranges, almonds, and coconut together in a large bowl.
In a separate bowl, whisk together the mayonnaise, curry powder, soy sauce, lemon juice, and dried minced onion.
Add the dressing to the salad and mix well.
Allow the salad to stand for several hours, preferably 12 hours or overnight, before serving.
Serve on lettuce leaves.
notes: Green seedless grapes may be used as a substitute for mandarin oranges.

fields.name: Fresh Peach Jell-O Salad
fields.title: Fresh Peach Jell-o Salad
fields.description: A refreshing jello salad made with fresh peaches, applesauce, and lemon-lime soda.
ingredients: 1 (12 oz) can or 1 1/2 cups lemon-lime soda
instructions: In a saucepan, combine the lemon jello and lemon-lime soda. The mixture will fizz.
Heat over low heat until the jello is dissolved (about 3 minutes).
Remove from heat and stir in the applesauce.
Refrigerate the mixture until it is almost set.
In a separate bowl, whip the cream.
Add the sugar and vanilla to the whipped cream.
Peel and dice the fresh peaches and mix them with the lemon or lime juice.
Gently fold the whipped cream and peaches into the jello mixture.
Pour the mixture into a 9x9 or 8x11 inch dish and refrigerate until set.

fields.name: Ham Loaf (2)
fields.title: Ham Loaf
fields.description: A savory loaf made with ground ham, bread crumbs, and a sweet pineapple glaze.
ingredients: 2 cups bread crumbs (4 slices bread cubed)
instructions: Mix with Meat mixture.
Bake 1 hr at 375 degrees.
Top with: 3/4 c. brown sugar, 1 1/2 T prepared mustard, 1/2 c. crushed pineapple, and 2 T vinegar.
Bake an additional 30 minutes at 325 degrees.

fields.name: Hamburger Casserole
fields.title: Hamburger Casserole
fields.description: A classic comfort food casserole featuring hamburger, peas, celery, cream of mushroom soup, and a crispy potato chip topping.
instructions: Brown meat & onion.
Add seasonings.
Cook peas until barely done.
Put meat in dish, then peas, celery and then soup.
Top with potato chips.

fields.name: Manti Pageant Marinade And London Broil Marinade
fields.image: images/adds/manti pageant marinade and london broil marinade.png
fields.title: Marinade for Turkey & Chicken & London Broil
fields.description: Two marinade recipes, one for poultry and one for beef.

instructions: Marinate overnight and then grill.
Mix together and marinate overnight.

fields.name: Peach Strawberry Jam
fields.title: Peach Strawberry Jam
fields.description: A sweet and fruity jam made with peaches, raspberries, and jello.
instructions: Boil peaches and sugar for 20 minutes.
Add raspberry jello and frozen raspberries.
Seal and process for 15 minutes.
notes: The original recipe did not explicitly mention the raspberries as part of the boiling process, so they were added with the jello.  If you would prefer a stronger raspberry flavor, you can incorporate part or all of the raspberries with the initial boiling.
fields.comment: Jello is a key ingredient to create the necessary pectin needed for a jam texture without needing additional pectin.

fields.name: Pineapple Cookies (2)
fields.title: Pineapple Cookies
fields.description: Sweet and tangy cookies bursting with pineapple flavor.
instructions: Cream the sugar, shortening, eggs, brown sugar, and vanilla together.
Mix the crushed pineapple with 1 tsp of soda and add it to the sugar mixture.
Add the flour to the sugar mixture.
Mix in the baking powder.
Bake at 400 degrees for 10-15 minutes.

fields.name: Pink Lemonade Dessert
fields.title: Lemonade Dessert
fields.description: A frozen dessert made with pink lemonade, vanilla wafers, and vanilla ice cream.
instructions: Place crums on bottom and then add ice cream mixture on top.
Place in freezer.

fields.name: Poppy Seed Cake
fields.title: Poppy Seed Cake
fields.description: A delicious poppy seed cake made with flour, sugar, eggs, oil or butter, milk, and flavorings.
ingredients: 1 1/2 c. oil or scant cup oil & 1/2 cube butter softened
instructions: Combine dry ingredients
Grease and flour pans.
Bake at 375 degrees for 45-60 minutes

fields.name: Refrigerator Chocolate Candy
fields.title: Refrigerator Chocolate Candy
fields.description: A simple no-bake dessert made with melted chocolate, Cool Whip, and vanilla wafer crumbs.
ingredients: 3 Hershey Bars (7 oz) almond or plain
instructions: Melt chocolate in double boiler.
Mix in cool whip.
Shape in balls and roll in crumbs.
Refrigerate.

fields.name: Rice Krispie Treats
fields.title: Rice Krispie Treats
fields.description: A classic no-bake dessert made with rice krispies, marshmallows, and butter.
ingredients: 10 oz pack (40) reg. marshmallows or 4 c. mini
instructions: Melt butter and marshmallows in pan.
Add rice krispies

fields.name: Stewed Tomatoes
fields.title: Stewed Tomatoes
fields.description: A simple stewed tomatoes recipe from Mam.
instructions: Cut tomatoes in smaller pieces.

fields.name: Tomatoes
fields.title: Tomatoes
fields.description: A simple recipe featuring tomatoes, seasoned with salt and sugar.

fields.name: Tortilla Chicken
fields.title: Tortilla Chicken
fields.description: A creamy chicken casserole made with tortillas, cream of chicken soup, and cheese.
instructions: Boil chicken breasts until tender. Remove and debone. Tear up tortillas into 1 inch squares.
Mix all ingredients except cheese and put in large flat casserole dish.
Bake 25 min. in 350 degree oven.
Remove and top with cheese. Bake 10 min. more.
Remove and let stand for 5 min.
